title: ENT Consultation - Deviated Septum and Nasal Congestion
summary: Patient consulted for deviated septum and nasal congestion. Doctor explained the anatomy of the nasal septum and turbinates, and how a deviated septum causes fixed obstruction while turbinate swelling causes variable obstruction. Patient has deviation on the left side in the front and lower part. Doctor recommended trying saline spray followed by Flonase twice daily to control turbinate swelling, then adding nasal strips to evaluate effectiveness before considering surgery. Weight was noted as a factor affecting snoring through throat obstruction. Follow-up scheduled after trial period of treatments.

reason_for_visit.description: Patient has a deviated septum on the left side in the front and lower part causing nasal obstruction
Patient inquired about whether treatment would help with snoring

details.title: Deviated Septum
details.description: The nasal septum is deviated on the left side in the front and lower part, creating a fixed obstruction that doesn't change

details.title: Turbinate Swelling
details.description: Variable nasal obstruction caused by turbinate swelling, which can contribute 20% to 50% or more of the obstruction. Turbinates swell due to nasal cycles, allergies, weather, surrounding conditions, and body position

todos.title: Saline and Flonase spray for nasal congestion
todos.description: Use saline spray first to moisturize the nose and reduce side effects of dryness, followed by Flonase to reduce inflammation and control turbinate swelling. Can be used once or twice a day, or during times when the nose is more congested. By doing the combination, you benefit from Flonase but the nose doesn't get dry.

todos.title: Nasal strips
todos.description: After trying the sprays for a few weeks, add nasal strips to evaluate if there is a significant increase in advantage

follow_up.description: Come back with questions about what has worked and what hasn't. If not satisfied with conservative treatments, can discuss moving forward with surgery

learnings.title: Deviated Septum
learnings.description: The septum is a dividing wall running from the tip of the nose made of plates of cartilage. Any part of the septum can be crooked, going one way or the other. This creates a fixed obstruction that narrows the nasal passageway and doesn't change.

learnings.title: Turbinates
learnings.description: Turbinates are structures in everyone's nose that can get swollen and cause variable obstruction. They swell due to natural nasal cycles where one side is swollen and the other is not, and this goes back and forth. They are also affected by allergies, weather, surrounding conditions, and body position. When lying down on one side, the turbinate on that side gets more swollen.

learnings.title: Weight and Snoring
learnings.description: Weight matters more for the throat when it comes to snoring. When going into deep sleep, muscle tone is lost. Extra weight in the neck and throat can cause the airway to collapse, making it smaller and causing snoring. Snoring can be from the throat, not just from the nose.

learnings.title: Treatment Approach
learnings.description: Try one thing at a time to evaluate effectiveness. Start with controlling turbinate swelling using sprays, then add nasal strips. This approach helps determine what works before considering surgical options for the deviated septum.
